instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> run slow with battery
threads.message:
When only with battery, it runs slowly.

<SIGNAL>HS_OTHER_IOUT</SIGNAL> - 1.27V
<SIGNAL>PBUS_S0_VSENSE</SIGNAL> - 0V ??
<SIGNAL>PBUSVSENS_EN_L</SIGNAL> - 11.17V

I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U5410</CHIP> as they were corroded. Could be something more?

ASD errors: Battery  RA table test Value over 2K found in R-a 0-7
VP0R pbus test

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> run slow with battery
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PBUS_S0_VSENSE</SIGNAL> 0V is of course not correct and should give an error in ASD too. Something wrong with <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> or corroded traces.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> run slow with battery
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PBUS_S0_VSENSE</SIGNAL> shoud not be in 0V only with battery??

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> run slow with battery
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PBUS_S0_VSENSE</SIGNAL> should never be 0V.

Is it 0V only on the battery or is it always at 0V?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> run slow with battery
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> run slow with battery
threads.message: pin 2 should be high of course as it comes directly from <SIGNAL>SLP_S3</SIGNAL>. Corroded trace or bad soldering.
